transcript.default: ʔaamumɬʔaƛquu nay̓aqak, ʔayaakitʔaaɬ qʷaqʷaaʔaaḥii ʔuuksnaʕaaɬ c̓aḥʷackʷi. ʔan ʔuutaqitʔaaɬ waɬyaqiɬḥ.

transcription.default: ʔaamumɬʔaƛquu nay̓aqak ʔayaakitʔaaɬ qʷaqʷaaʔaaḥii ʔuuksnaʕaaɬ c̓aḥʷackʷi ʔan ʔuutaqitʔaaɬ waɬyaqiɬḥ

translation.eng: When a baby was born, they used to do many things with the afterbirth, since they used to take care of it at home.
They buried it [carefully]. They didn’t just bury it or throw it away.

transcript.default: ʔuuksnaʕaaɬʔaƛquu qʷiimaʕukmaḥsaʔitq ḥaakʷaaƛ. ƛ̓aʕiiksap t̓ut̓unaxk̓uk, pic̓up, č̓itapt. qʷiqʔiitq pikaʔuuqiiɬy̓ak (paaskitiiɬy̓ak). ƛ̓aʕiiksap̓aƛ, c̓uy̓iitap̓aƛ.

transcription.default: ʔuuksnaʕaaɬʔaƛquu qʷiimaʕukmaḥsaʔitq ḥaakʷaaƛ ƛ̓aʕiiksap t̓ut̓unaxk̓uk pic̓up č̓itapt qʷiqʔiitq pikaʔuuqiiɬy̓ak paaskitiiɬy̓ak ƛ̓aʕiiksap̓aƛ c̓uy̓iitap̓aƛ

translation.eng: They took whatever they wanted the girl to be talented at and wrap it [with the afterbirth]: they put things like tule grass, cedar bark, swamp grass, or whatever they used to make baskets with.
They didn’t just bury it — they prayed as they are doing it.
And for boys too, they did all sorts of things.

transcript.default: ʔuuwink̓ap̓at čiicy̓akštup, qʷaaqḥcumʔitq wiicaḥi ʔuʔuʔiiḥʔaƛquu muwač hihiqtup.

transcription.default: ʔuuwink̓ap̓at čiicy̓akštup qʷaaqḥcumʔitq wiicaḥi ʔuʔuʔiiḥʔaƛquu muwač hihiqtup

translation.eng: They used to put fishing gear or whatever that would make him well-off when he hunted for deer and so on.

transcript.default: y̓uuqʷaa ʔuuksnaʕaaɬʔat c̓uy̓iitapw̓it̓asʔaƛquu c̓aḥʷackʷi. y̓uuqʷaa č̓iima, qʷiimaʕukmaḥsap̓atʔitq ʕaakʕaakʷa.

transcription.default: y̓uuqʷaa ʔuuksnaʕaaɬʔat c̓uy̓iitapw̓it̓asʔaƛquu c̓aḥʷackʷi y̓uuqʷaa č̓iima qʷiimaʕukmaḥsap̓atʔitq ʕaakʕaakʷa

translation.eng: Also they used to bury with the afterbirth a knife and whatever you would want him to be talented at carving.
That’s what they used to do a long time ago.
People were still doing that until recently.
I know one girl from Ahousaht.
She went to school for a long time and became a lawyer.
They had buried [for her] paper and pencils with the afterbirth.
And it also happened to my stepdaughter.
Her grandmother put in playing cards.
Because of that, they also made her well-off.
